dt: {bc}a person who puts on a false appearance of {d_link|virtue|virtue} or religion
{bc}a person who acts in contradiction to his or her stated beliefs or feelings

quotes.t: Of all of these things and people Cilla knew nothing, nor could he tell her, yet he tried to show interest in what she had to tell him. Once he would have been very interested. Now he felt like a {qword}hypocrite{/qword}, and because he was uncomfortable he blamed it in some way on Cilla.

We can learn a good deal about the manners and morals of the times from Lautrec, for he was neither a {qword}hypocrite{/qword} nor a sentimentalist, and there is a matter-of-fact-ness about his vision … that precludes both nostalgia and prurience.

Holding up high moral, ethical, and social standards is very difficult, because if one falls short of being a perfect example, one becomes a target and a {qword}hypocrite{/qword}, albeit a well-meaning one.

et: Middle English {it}ypocrite,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}ipocrite,{/it} borrowed from Late Latin {it}hypocrita,{/it} borrowed from Greek {it}hypokritḗs{/it} "answerer, actor on a stage, pretender," from {it}hypokri-,{/it} variant stem of {it}hypokrī́nomai, hypokrī́nesthai{/it} "to reply, make an answer, speak in dialogue, play a part on the stage, feign" + {it}-tēs,{/it} agent suffix {ma}{mat|hypocrisy|}{/ma}
